summary: a 34-year-old nurse developed shortness of breath, cough, and agitation after denatonium benzoate fit testing. she had a history of allergy to disinfecting products (containing quaternary ammonium) denatonium benzoate is a useful indicator to ensure that the respirator being used by an individual forms a tight enough seal to adequately protect against unwanted airborne exposures. the main purpose of fit testing is to ensure that the respirator being used by the individual forms a tight enough seal to protect against unwanted airborne exposures. the test criterion of the respirator fit test is the failure to taste the denatonium benzoate by the examinee. a few scattered rales and wheezing sounds were heard upon examination of the lungs. an electrocardiogram revealed a sinus rhythm with a heart rate of 78 beats/min. the symptoms of dyspnea improved. she was discharged in stable condition and sent to rest at home. she was referred to a medical center hospital in southern Taiwan. informed written consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and accompanying image. informed written consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and accompanying image. exposure to denatonium benzoate may have a role in adverse reactions. urticaria, asthma, asthma, angioedema, asthma, angioedema and asthma. exposure to chemicals and fragrances may cause asthma. the patient's symptoms of difficulty breathing began when she was exposed to denatonium benzoate. this case indicates that there may be potentially significant health risks associated with denatonium benzoate-based fit testing. more advanced research is required in the future.
